question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will the maximum weekly rate of hospitalizations per 100,000 in the US occur within four weeks of the combined peak for each of COVID, influenza, and RSV in the 2023-24 season?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the maximum weekly rate of hospitalizations per 100,000 for each of COVID, influenza, and RSV that occurs in the 2023-24 season is less than or equal to four weeks (28 days) from the date of the maximum rate for all three combined, according to the CDC's [RESP-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/surveillance/resp-net/dashboard.html). The four weeks will be based on the week end dates. The CDC uses "epidemiological weeks" which begin on Sunday and end on Saturday. The rate used will be that for all ages, races, and sexes. See the fine print for the correct filters. For the purposes of this question, the 2023-2024 season will be considered to begin with the week ending on October 7, 2023, and end on the week ending June 1, 2024.

To allow for data revisions and reporting delays the question will resolve according to data shown after the reporting delay period, when the relevant figures for the current season is not shown as a dashed line, typically 4 weeks after the week end date.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the patterns of COVID, influenza, and RSV hospitalization rates in the US, specifically focusing on the 2023-24 season. Typically, the peak hospitalization rates for these three viruses occur within a few weeks of each other. However, the exact timing and duration of these peaks can vary from year to year. Historically, the peak hospitalization rates for COVID, influenza, and RSV have often occurred within a similar timeframe, with some overlap. For instance, during the 2022-23 season, the peak hospitalization rates for COVID, influenza, and RSV occurred within a 4-week window. However, there have been instances where the peaks have been more spread out, such as in the 2020-21 season when the COVID peak occurred much later than the peaks for influenza and RSV. Given the current data and trends, it is difficult to predict with certainty whether the maximum weekly rate of hospitalizations per 100,000 for each of COVID, influenza, and RSV will occur within four weeks of the combined peak for all three in the 2023-24 season. However, considering the historical patterns and the typical overlap of these peaks, it is plausible that the maximum weekly rates for all three viruses will occur within a relatively close timeframe.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

The film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million domestically, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time. However, it's worth noting that the record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is currently held by the original Deadpool, and it's uncertain whether the new movie will top these marks. The resolution will be based on reports from the Hollywood Reporter or equivalent publication, which will confirm the global opening weekend gross and whether it sets a new record for R-rated movies.

However, during intense space weather events, the Kp index can rise above 5, often as a result of high-speed solar wind or coronal mass ejections (CMEs) interacting with the Earth's magnetic field. These events are generally unpredictable and occur less frequently, but they can have a significant impact on Earth's magnetic field and geomagnetic activity.

Considering these factors, while there is a reasonable chance that the strongest storm between July 17 and July 28, 2024, will have a Kp index greater than 5, it's not as likely as other possible scenarios. question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

Additionally, there are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, with at least one calling on Biden to end his campaign. These indicators suggest that there is a significant amount of pressure building from within the Democratic Party to have Biden drop out. Given the urgency and the fact that there are already multiple members working together behind the scenes, it is likely that a group of at least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators will work together to ask Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

This suggests that there is a significant number of Democrats who are unsettled about the plan and are willing to take a public stance against it. However, the exact number of signatures required to resolve the market in the affirmative is 20, which is a relatively high threshold. While the effort to oppose the plan is underway, it's uncertain whether it will be successful in gathering enough signatures to meet this threshold. Given the information provided, there are several factors that contribute to the uncertainty: 1. The existence of a drafted letter suggests that there is a group of Democrats willing to speak out against the plan, but it's unclear how many signatures it will ultimately gather. 2. The fact that Rep. Huffman declined to confirm the existence of the letter, but still expressed his opposition to the plan, implies that there may be some level of support for the effort, but it's not a guarantee of success. 3. The market resolves YES if 20 or more signatures are obtained, which is a relatively high bar to clear. Considering these factors, I believe that while there is a reasonable chance that at least 20 House or Senate Democrats will sign the letter, the uncertainty surrounding the number of signatures and the potential for multiple letters with combined signatures makes it a challenging task to meet the threshold.

question.title: Did someone intentionally shoot at Trump on July 13th?

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: The likelihood of the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to declare the President incapacitated before August 2024 seems low for several reasons. Firstly, there is no clear indication that President Biden is unfit to discharge his duties. The context of the question mentions a GOP lawmaker's request to Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment, but this does not necessarily imply a majority of the Cabinet is inclined to take such an action. Moreover, Section 4 of the 25th Amendment is rarely invoked, and there would need to be a clear and compelling reason for such a drastic measure to be taken. Without any information suggesting a majority of the Cabinet is working to have Biden declared incapacitated, and given the rarity of invoking Section 4, I consider the likelihood of this event occurring before August 2024 to be very low.

question.title: Will at least 30% of Manifold respondents agree that weak AGI had been achieved before July 23, 2024?
question.body:
[image]Every month, a Manifold poll is being posted to gain the consensus view of progress towards AGI. Unlike many of the markets and questions on Manifold, these polls will simply ask "has weak AGI been achieved," rather than providing a definition of the term. The goal is that given that the term is so broad, the only way to characterize AI progress is also to allow respondents to vote based upon their own understanding.

Progress has been steady.  The previous polls are referenced here:

@/SteveSokolowski/did-openai-achieve-weak-agi-with-gp  (Answer: 15)

@/SteveSokolowski/june-2024-has-weak-agi-been-achieve  (Answer: 27)

The previous markets on this topic, which significantly understimated Manifold's belief in AI progress, were:

@/SteveSokolowski/what-percentage-of-manifold-poll-re 

@/SteveSokolowski/will-at-least-20-of-manifold-respon 

The polls will not reference any specific model, and will not define "AGI" except to state that the poll does not require that the software system be able to manipulate the physical world. The polls open on the 23rd of each month and close on the 30th.

This market will resolve to YES if the July 2024 poll results in a ratio of YES/(NO + YES) greater than or equal to 0.3. The "no opinion" respondents will be ignored. Otherwise, this question will resolve to NO.

See also:

@/SteveSokolowski/will-one-of-the-monthly-has-weak-ag

The fact that the polls open on the 23rd and close on the 30th of each month suggests that the respondents are likely to be a subset of the same community that has been participating in the previous polls, which have shown steady progress. 5. The resolution criteria is based on the ratio of YES/(NO + YES) greater than or equal to 0.3, which suggests that a significant majority of respondents will need to agree on the achievement of weak AGI. Considering these factors, I would estimate that the probability of at least 30% of Manifold respondents agreeing that weak AGI has been achieved before July 23, 2024, is relatively high, but not extremely high. I would place this probability at around 60%.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the specification of the resolution date for July 19, it is likely that the prediction will be available on a Friday. According to our calendar, July 19, 2024 will be a Friday. Therefore, it is reasonable to infer that the 538 project will have made their predictions available by then, which would make Biden the favorite.

question.title: Iran military response before August 13th midnight Eastern Time?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Iran initiates a military action on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory between July 30 and August 12, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

For the purposes of this market, a "military action" will be considered to be any use of force executed by Iran on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory (e.g. if a weapons depot on Israeli soil is hit by an Iranian missile, this market will resolve to "Yes") that is officially acknowledged by the Iranian government or a consensus of credible reporting. This includes, but is not limited to, airstrikes, naval attacks, or ground invasions. Cyber attacks, sanctions, or diplomatic actions will not count towards the resolution of this market.

Only responses by Iranian forces explicitly claimed by the Islamic Republic of Iran, or confirmed to have originated from Iranian territory will count toward the resolution of this market. Attacks on Israel by proxy forces (i.e. Hezbollah, Houthis, etc.) will not count toward the resolution of this market.

This suggests that any military action would require a level of planning and coordination, which could reduce the likelihood of an impulsive or uncoordinated attack. Thirdly, the market explicitly excludes attacks by proxy forces, which could reduce the likelihood of a military action initiated by Iran. However, it's worth noting that proxy forces like Hezbollah or Houthis could still potentially be involved in a military action, but this would not be counted towards the resolution of the market. Considering these factors, while there are valid reasons to be concerned about the potential for a military action, the requirement for official acknowledgement or credible reporting from Iranian territory and the exclusion of proxy forces may reduce the likelihood of such an event. However, the exact probability is difficult to estimate without more information.

https://manifold.markets/news/shortfuse-one-piece

I am basing this off of GMT-7 time zone for July 18th If they release chapter 1122 between 00:00:00 and 23:59:59, this question will resolve as “YES.” Anything else will resolve as “NO.”

TCB Scans usually posts the chapter on the Thursday before official release. 1121. 1120, 1119, 1118, 1117, 1116 and 1115 were Thursdays. 1114 was a Thursday, May 9th. 1113 was a Friday, April 25th. 1112 was a Friday, April 19. 1111 will be uploaded March 22, a Friday. 1110 was uploaded March 15th, a Friday. 1109 was uploaded March 1, a Friday. 1108 was February 22, 1107 was February 15, both Thursdays. 

TCB has started posting on Fridays after the twitter account ban. Unknown if this shall continue, thought I’d put the info here for investors.

I do not answer my own questions.

Since chapter 1113 was uploaded on a Friday (April 25th) and chapter 1111 will be uploaded on a Friday (March 22nd), it seems that TCB Scans might continue posting on Fridays. However, it's also possible that they might return to posting on Thursdays. Given that chapter 1122 would be released on August 1st, if TCB Scans continue to post on Fridays, they would upload chapter 1122 on August 2nd, which is after the resolution date. Therefore, the probability of this scenario resolving as 'YES' is low. However, if TCB Scans return to posting on Thursdays, they would upload chapter 1122 on August 1st, which aligns with the resolution date. This scenario is possible, but we don't have enough information to determine if they will return to posting on Thursdays. Considering these factors, I would assign a low probability to the question resolving as 'YES' on August 1st.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment disqualifies individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding public office. This provision has been invoked in the past, such as in the case of former Confederate officials after the Civil War. However, the application of Section 3 to a former President like Donald Trump is unprecedented and highly contentious. While there have been efforts to invoke Section 3 against Trump, these have been met with significant resistance and legal challenges. The outcome of these efforts is uncertain and may depend on various factors, including the specific state laws and court decisions. Given the complexity and uncertainty surrounding the application of Section 3, it is difficult to predict with certainty whether Trump will be removed or blocked from any state's primary election ballot. However, considering the ongoing efforts to invoke Section 3 against Trump and the potential for court decisions or state government actions, I estimate that there is a non-negligible probability that Trump will be removed or blocked from at least one state's primary election ballot.

question.title: [Short Fuse] Will the proxy advisor Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) advise Tesla shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $57 billion package OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk?
question.body: The question will resolve **Yes** if Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) releases a statement explicitly advising Tesla shareholders to vote *against* Elon Musk's pay package at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk to the Tesla board of directors. Otherwise the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) will advise Tesla shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $57 billion package or the re-election of Kimbal Musk, I consider the following factors: 1. ISS's role as a proxy advisor: ISS is a well-established and respected proxy advisory firm that provides guidance to institutional investors on how to vote on corporate governance matters, including executive compensation and board elections. 2. Tesla's history of controversy: Elon Musk's compensation package has been a subject of controversy among investors and governance experts, with some arguing that it is excessive and not aligned with the company's long-term interests. 3. ISS's voting history: ISS has a history of advising against excessive executive compensation packages, and has been critical of similar packages in the past. 4. The size and scope of the package: The $57 billion package is one of the largest in corporate history, and may be seen as excessive by ISS and other governance experts. 5. The re-election of Kimbal Musk: Kimbal Musk is a member of the Tesla board of directors and has been involved in the company's governance and decision-making processes. ISS may have concerns about his re-election, particularly if they believe he is not providing adequate oversight of Elon Musk's compensation package. Considering these factors, I believe that ISS is likely to advise against Elon Musk's compensation package and/or the re-election of Kimbal Musk. However, without access to ISS's internal deliberations and voting guidelines, it is impossible to predict with certainty how they will advise Tesla shareholders.

ISS's role as a proxy advisor: ISS provides non-binding recommendations to institutional investors on how to vote on shareholder proposals, including executive compensation and board elections. 2. ISS's general approach to executive compensation: ISS tends to be cautious when evaluating executive compensation packages, especially those that are perceived as excessive or not aligned with shareholder interests. 3. Elon Musk's pay package: The $57 billion package is a significant and highly publicized compensation deal. ISS might view it as excessive or not aligned with shareholder interests, especially given the company's financial performance and Musk's existing wealth. 4. Kimbal Musk's re-election: As a member of the Tesla board, Kimbal Musk's re-election might be influenced by ISS's assessment of the board's overall performance and composition. However, there are also reasons why ISS might not advise against the pay package or Kimbal Musk's re-election: 1. ISS's neutrality: As a proxy advisor, ISS strives to remain neutral and avoid taking a confrontational stance with companies or their executives. 2. Given these considerations, I believe that ISS is likely to advise against the pay package or Kimbal Musk's re-election, but the likelihood of a 'yes' outcome (i.e., ISS not advising against the pay package and Kimbal Musk's re-election) is still relatively low.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Russia having control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024, we need to consider various factors such as the current military situation in the region, the progress of the Ukrainian and Russian forces, and the information provided by the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map. question.title: Will Tucker Carlson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

However, his influence and popularity within the party do not necessarily translate to a nomination for President. 2. The Republican National Convention's nomination process: The Republican National Convention typically selects the party's nominee through a combination of delegate votes, with the winner being the candidate who receives a majority of the votes. While it's possible for a surprise candidate to emerge, the nomination process often favors more established and well-funded candidates. 3. Tucker Carlson's past statements and actions: Carlson has been a vocal critic of certain Republican Party leaders and has expressed views that may not align with the party's more moderate or establishment wings. Considering these factors, while Tucker Carlson is a well-known and influential figure in the Republican Party, his chances of being selected as the nominee seem low. question.title: Will Scotland hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is a referendum held in Scotland regarding Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom, and this referendum is held before May 3, 2024.  This referendum may be an "advisory" referendum; that is, it is not necessary for the referendum to have any legally binding effect.

It shall not be deemed resolved by a “wildcat” or “Catalan” style of referendum where the UK government has declined permission for the vote, nor by a vote organised by civil society institutions. A referendum must be deemed to have the consent of the London government

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability that Scotland will hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, I'll consider the following points: 1. The Scottish National Party (SNP), which has been a pro-independence party, has been in power in Scotland since 2007, with a majority in the Scottish Parliament since 2011. They have consistently pushed for a second independence referendum. 2. The UK government has been resistant to granting permission for a referendum, but it's not clear if they will maintain this stance in the long term. 3. The UK government's position on a second referendum is likely to be influenced by the outcome of the 2024 UK general election, which could lead to a change in the UK government's stance on Scottish independence. 4. There have been previous instances of the UK government granting permission for referendums on devolution, such as the 1997 and 2014 referendums, which suggests that they are willing to consider such requests. 5. The Scottish government has taken steps to prepare for a potential referendum, including establishing a National Assembly and conducting public consultations. Considering these points, it seems plausible that the Scottish government will continue to push for a referendum and that the UK government may eventually grant permission for one, especially if there is a change in government in 2024. However, there are also reasons to be cautious, such as the UK government's resistance to granting permission and the potential for a referendum to be delayed or blocked. Given these considerations, I estimate the probability that Scotland will hold an official, sanctioned referendum on independence before May 3, 2024, as follows:
